chunks.en: A shadow kept from childhood: 'Go make a toast to everyone'
On the first day of the Lunar New Year, I had dinner with relatives. At a large table, apart from me and a few peers (in their twenties), everyone else was an elder (in their fifties or sixties).

Halfway through the meal, my mom leaned over and told me to go around and make a toast to everyone, which meant drinking a glass with each family at the table and saying something like 'good health and all the best'.

It wouldn't have been difficult, but it was very annoying. Since elementary school, every time I attended a dinner gathering, my mom insisted that I do this. When I was a kid, I toasted with drinks, and all the kids at the table were encouraged by their parents to make a toast, and they even had to compete to see who could say it the nicest, and the adults at the table watched as if it were a performance.

What annoyed me even more was that with my mom's encouragement, I was stuck in an awkward position. If I went to make a toast, it seemed like I only did it because my mom reminded me, and it felt unnatural like I was performing.
If I didn't go, then it would be even more impolite, as if I was being asked to make a toast and I wouldn't.
But conversely, in her eyes, if she didn't remind me, I definitely wouldn't make a toast, and after she reminded me, at least I went.
Of course, she wasn't wrong, if she didn't encourage me, I definitely wouldn't do such a thing.
Although I can understand that this kind of thing, making a toast at the dinner table is equivalent to enlivening the atmosphere, it's just very annoying, a childhood shadow.
Buy a water gun and squirt everyone

I also asked an AI: This situation can be explained from several psychological angles: Power and control: The imposer may gain a sense of control or power by making you do things you don't want to do.
In psychology, this behavior may be related to power distance or dominant behavior.
Some people boost their self-esteem or satisfy certain psychological needs by controlling others.
Social norms and cultural pressure: In many cultures, toasting during the Lunar New Year is an important social etiquette, especially during reunions or celebrations.
The imposer may consider this a cultural or social necessity, and even if they know you don't want to, they insist on you participating out of adherence to tradition or social expectations.
Ignoring Other People's Boundaries (Boundary Violation): The imposer may lack respect or understanding for personal boundaries.
Psychologically, this may indicate a lack of emotional intelligence, especially in identifying and respecting the feelings and needs of others.

Cognitive Dissonance: The imposer may recognize your unwillingness, but due to the phenomenon of cognitive dissonance, they may rationalize their behavior, thinking it's 'for everyone's good' or 'this is tradition' to alleviate their guilt from pressuring you.

Compulsive Behavior: If this behavior occurs repeatedly, and the imposer insists even after being told, it may involve some degree of obsessive-compulsive personality traits or behavioral patterns, manifested as an obsession with specific behaviors or compulsiveness to force others to obey.
Communication Obstacles: There may be a lack of clear communication.
Your feedback may not have been effectively conveyed or understood by the imposer as unimportant, or they may have misunderstood the severity of the feedback.

In this case, you may want to consider the following strategies: Clear Communication: Express your unwillingness again clearly, explain why this behavior makes you uncomfortable, try to avoid being emotional, and use 'I' statements (such as 'I feel uncomfortable' instead of 'you make me uncomfortable').
Set Boundaries: Firmly but politely refuse, propose other acceptable alternatives, such as toasting can express blessings in other ways.

Seek Support: If the situation doesn't change, consider getting support from family or friends, or seeking professional psychological counseling to help deal with the stress in this interpersonal relationship.
Psychological explanations can help understand the motives behind this behavior, but changing this dynamic may require both parties to reflect and adjust.
